fact: Kyoto was Japan's capital for over 1,000 years and is famous for its historic temples and beautiful gardens.
Machu Picchu was built in the 15th century by the Inca Empire and is often called the 'Lost City of the Incas.'
Venice is made up of 118 small islands, separated by canals and connected by bridges.
Central Park in New York City is larger than the country of Monaco.
The Sydney Opera House's iconic design was inspired by the sails of boats in Sydney Harbor.
Reykjavik is the northernmost capital in the world and is known for its stunning views of the Northern Lights.
Cappadocia is famous for its 'fairy chimneys,' which are unique rock formations created by volcanic eruptions.
The Sagrada Familia in Barcelona has been under construction since 1882 and is expected to be completed in 2026.
Cape Town's Table Mountain is over 260 million years old, making it one of the oldest mountains in the world.
The Burj Khalifa in Dubai is the tallest building in the world, standing at 828 meters (2,717 feet).
The Eiffel Tower can be up to 15 cm taller in the summer due to the expansion of the metal in the heat.
The blue domes of Santorini's churches are meant to represent the sea and sky.
Rio de Janeiro is home to the world's largest Carnival festival, which attracts over 2 million people each year.
Rome has more fountains than any other city in the world, with over 1,500 fountains.
Petra is known as the 'Rose City' due to the pink-colored sandstone cliffs from which it was carved.
Prague's Astronomical Clock is the third-oldest astronomical clock in the world and the oldest one still in operation.
Bali is home to the world's largest turtle conservation center, dedicated to the protection of endangered sea turtles.
Vancouver has one of the mildest climates in Canada and is often ranked as one of the world's most livable cities.
Edinburgh is the world's first UNESCO City of Literature, a title it earned in 2004.
Amsterdam's canals cover more than 100 kilometers and have 1,500 bridges, earning it the nickname 'Venice of the North.'
Jerusalem is considered a holy city by three major religions: Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.
Lisbon is older than Rome, making it one of the oldest cities in Western Europe.
The Great Pyramid of Giza, located just outside of Cairo, is the last remaining wonder of the ancient world.
Buenos Aires is known as the 'Paris of South America' due to its European-style architecture and vibrant culture.
Kyiv is home to one of the deepest metro stations in the world, Arsenalna, which is 105.5 meters below ground.
Stockholm is built on 14 islands, connected by more than 50 bridges.
Marrakech's Medina is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, known for its vibrant souks (markets) and stunning palaces.
Athens is one of the oldest cities in the world, with recorded history going back over 3,400 years.
Bangkok's real name is the longest city name in the world, containing 169 characters in Thai.
Berlin has more museums than rainy days in a year, with over 180 museums to explore.
Hanoi is known for its centuries-old architecture and a rich culture with Southeast Asian, Chinese, and French influences.
Bruges is often called the 'Venice of the North' due to its canals and medieval buildings.
Florence is considered the birthplace of the Renaissance and is home to Michelangelo's famous statue of David.
Seoul is home to five grand palaces, including the famous Gyeongbokgung Palace, which was built in 1395.
Moscow's Red Square is not named for the color red or its association with communism, but from the word 'krasnaya,' meaning 'beautiful' in old Russian.
Krakow's Main Square is the largest medieval town square in Europe, covering about 40,000 square meters.
Zanzibar is known as the 'Spice Island' due to its vast production of cloves, cinnamon, and nutmeg.
Salzburg is the birthplace of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and the setting for the famous movie 'The Sound of Music.'
Budapest is actually made up of three cities: Buda, Obuda, and Pest, which were united in 1873.
Hong Kong has more skyscrapers than any other city in the world, with over 8,000 buildings standing taller than 14 stories.
Brisbane is known as the 'River City,' with the Brisbane River winding its way through the heart of the city.
Auckland is home to the Sky Tower, the tallest freestanding structure in the Southern Hemisphere, standing at 328 meters.
Casablanca is home to the Hassan II Mosque, which has the tallest minaret in the world at 210 meters.
Helsinki has been ranked one of the most livable cities in the world and is known for its design and architecture.
Tallinn's Old Town is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, famous for its medieval architecture and cobblestone streets.
Lima was the most important city in Spanish South America during colonial times and is home to the oldest university in the Americas, founded in 1551.
Oslo is one of the world's greenest cities, with vast forest areas within the city limits and 343 lakes.
Dubrovnik's Old Town is completely encircled by well-preserved medieval walls, and is known as the 'Pearl of the Adriatic.'
Copenhagen is known for its bike culture, with over 50% of its residents commuting to work or school by bicycle.
Cusco was once the capital of the Inca Empire and sits at an elevation of 3,399 meters (11,152 feet) above sea level.
Queenstown is known as the adventure capital of the world, offering activities like bungee jumping, skydiving, and white-water rafting.
Chiang Mai is home to over 300 temples, with some dating back to the 13th century when the city was founded.
Havana's Old Town, known as Habana Vieja, is a UNESCO World Heritage site with over 900 buildings of historical importance.
Siem Reap is the gateway to the Angkor Archaeological Park, which contains the remains of the Khmer Empire's different capitals from the 9th to 15th centuries.
Quito, the capital of Ecuador, was the first city to be declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1978.
Cartagena's walled city and fortress, built in the 16th century, is one of the most well-preserved examples of Spanish colonial architecture in South America.
Luang Prabang is known for its daily alms-giving ceremony, where hundreds of monks collect offerings from locals and tourists at dawn.
Jaipur is known as the 'Pink City' due to the distinctive color of its buildings, which were painted pink to welcome the Prince of Wales in 1876.
Porto is famous for its port wine production and is home to the spectacular Livraria Lello, often cited as one of the world's most beautiful bookstores.
Fes is home to the world's oldest university, the University of Al Quaraouiyine, founded in 859 AD.
Wrocław is known for its population of small bronze gnome statues scattered throughout the city, with over 350 of these whimsical figures.
Hoi An's Ancient Town is a remarkably well-preserved example of a Southeast Asian trading port from the 15th to 19th centuries.
Valparaíso is known for its colorful clifftop homes and its unique system of funiculars that help residents navigate the steep hills.
Lake Bled features a small island with a church, where it's tradition for a groom to carry his bride up the 99 steps for good luck.
Annecy is often called the 'Venice of the Alps' due to its system of canals and the picturesque old town built around them.
Antigua is renowned for its well-preserved Spanish Baroque-influenced architecture and the ruins of colonial churches.
Bukhara's historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site, with over 140 architectural monuments dating back to the Middle Ages.
Sintra is famous for its colorful palaces, including the Pena Palace, which looks like it came straight out of a fairytale.
Vigan is one of the best-preserved examples of a planned Spanish colonial town in Asia, with its cobblestone streets and unique architecture.
Lalibela is home to 11 rock-hewn churches, carved entirely out of a single block of granite with its roof at ground level.
Kotor's Old Town is tucked in a secluded part of the Gulf of Kotor, surrounded by dramatic limestone cliffs.
Guanajuato is known for its network of underground tunnels that serve as roads, originally built to prevent flooding.
Český Krumlov's castle complex is the second largest in the Czech Republic, after Prague Castle.
Gjirokastër is known as the 'City of Stone' due to its distinctive Ottoman-era stone houses and castle.
Nara is famous for its free-roaming deer, considered sacred messengers of the gods in the Shinto religion.
Colmar's old town is often called 'Little Venice' due to its canals, colorful half-timbered houses, and flower-lined streets.
San Miguel de Allende is known for its colonial architecture and vibrant arts scene, with no traffic lights in its historic center.
Mdina, known as the 'Silent City,' is a fortified medieval town that serves as a prime example of an ancient walled city.
Mostar is famous for its iconic Stari Most (Old Bridge), a 16th-century Ottoman bridge destroyed in 1993 and rebuilt in 2004.
Hội An is renowned for its monthly lantern festival, where the town turns off its electric lights and is illuminated solely by colorful lanterns.
Sighișoara is the birthplace of Vlad the Impaler, the historical inspiration for Bram Stoker's Dracula.
Plovdiv is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in Europe, with a history spanning over 8,000 years.
Arequipa is known as the 'White City' due to its buildings made from sillar, a white volcanic rock.
Ghent's historic center is home to more than 900 listed buildings, including the famous Gravensteen castle.
Barichara is often called Colombia's prettiest town, known for its well-preserved colonial architecture and cobblestone streets.
Rothenburg ob der Tauber is one of the best-preserved medieval towns in Europe, with its town walls still largely intact.
Ait Benhaddou is a fortified village (ksar) that has been featured in numerous films, including Gladiator and Game of Thrones.
Yangon is home to the Shwedagon Pagoda, a 2,500-year-old Buddhist temple covered in gold leaf and diamonds.
Suzdal, part of Russia's Golden Ring, has over 200 architectural and historical monuments, despite having a population of only about 10,000.
Óbidos is a small medieval town completely enclosed by ancient walls, and was traditionally given as a wedding gift to Portuguese queens.
Hvar is known for its lavender fields, and is said to receive more hours of sunshine than any other place in Europe.
Gyeongju, once the capital of the ancient kingdom of Silla, is often called 'the museum without walls' due to its abundance of historical sites.
Lucerne is home to the Chapel Bridge, the oldest covered wooden bridge in Europe, originally built in the 14th century.
Valladolid is known for its cenotes, natural sinkholes filled with freshwater that were sacred to the ancient Maya civilization.
Nantes is home to Les Machines de l'île, a unique artistic project featuring giant mechanical animals, including a 12-meter-tall elephant that visitors can ride.
Yazd is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world, known for its unique Persian architecture and wind-catching towers.
Hallstatt is so picturesque that a full-scale replica of the entire town was built in China's Guangdong province.
Burano is famous for its brightly colored houses, which follow a specific color system established centuries ago.
Galle's fortified old town, founded by Portuguese colonists in the 16th century, is a unique blend of European architecture and South Asian traditions.
Ifrane, with its alpine-style architecture, is often called 'Little Switzerland' due to its resemblance to a Swiss mountain resort.
Visby, on the island of Gotland, is one of the best-preserved medieval cities in Scandinavia, with its 13th-century ring wall still largely intact.
